citation.article-title: Heliophilum fasciatum gen. nov. sp. nov. and Heliobacterium gestii sp. nov.: endospore-forming heliobacteria from rice field soils.

p.s: Description of Heliobacterium gestii sp. nov.
Heliobacterium gestii (named in honor of Howard Gest, an American microbiologist within whose laboratory the heliobacteria were first discovered)
Motile by polar or subpolar flagella.
Cells lack intracytoplasmic photosynthetic membranes or chlorosomes.
Heat-resistant endospores produced in newly isolated cultures.

Cells contain bacteriochlorophyll g and grow photoheterotrophically on acetate (plus CO2), butyrate (plus CO2), pyruvate, lactate, fructose, glucose, or ribose, or chemotrophically in darkness by pyruvate fermentation.
Utilizable nitrogen sources include ammonia, glutamine, and N2.
Absorption maxima of intact cells (maintained under anoxic conditions) at 788, 480, and 415 nm.
Color of cell suspensions, green to brownish green.
Cells exposed to light and oxygen turn emerald green.
Optimal growth temperature about 40° C, optimal pH is 7.
Some strains lack capacity for assimilatory sulfate reduction; sulfide, methionine, cysteine, or thiosulfate is then required for growth.
NaCl not required, growth inhibited above 1% NaCl.
The type strain is H. gestii Chainat (G+C = 55.1 mol%) isolated from a Thailand rice soil, and is deposited in the American Type Culture Collection as ATCC 43375.
